posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

There is intergenerational trauma, but it's of a different kind. It's called "cultural cringe"

i'll just post it cause the wannabe paddy yank cocksucker won't post it

The Argus newspaper of 4 December 1854 reported that the Union Jack "had" to be hoisted underneath the Eureka Flag at the stockade and that both flags were in possession of the foot police.[119] Peter FitzSimons has questioned whether this contemporaneous report of the otherwise unaccounted-for Union Jack known as the Eureka Jack being present is accurate.[120] Among those willing to credit the first report of the battle as being true and correct it has been theorised that the hoisting of a Union Jack at the stockade was possibly an 11th-hour response to the divided loyalties among the heterogeneous rebel force which was in the process of melting away.[121] At one point up to 1,500 of 17,280 men in Ballarat were garrisoning the stockade, with as few as 120 taking part in the battle.[citation needed] Lalor's choice of password for the night of 2 December – "Vinegar Hill"[122][123][15] – causing support for the rebellion to fall away among those who were otherwise disposed to resist the military, as word spread that the question of Irish home rule had become involved. One survivor of the battle stated that "the collapse of the rising at Ballarat may be regarded as mainly attributable to the password given by Lalor on the night before the assault." Asked by one of his subordinates for the "night pass," he gave "Vinegar Hill," the site of a battle during the 1798 Irish rebellion.

Federation took decades of work to be a success, it was not a popular idea, and it took two constitutional conventions to get anything rolling. Smaller colonies feared domination from NSW and Victoria; all states hated Queensland's continued practice of blackbirding and use of South Seas Islanders on plantations out of fear of job security (and a moral undertone); and concern over tariffs.
Sure, there were proponents of federation, but people identified with their colony. WA by virtue of never being under NSW and so distant, SA by virtue of free settlement and religious equality, Victoria by wealth, NSW by primacy, Qld by its agrarian practices; and Tasmania by being a far off island with a different climate and response to Aboriginals.

SA was initially the main place which accepted Germans, with Old Lutherans from Prussia & Silesia and later Catholic Rhinelanders in the Barossa Valley, up through the Riverland, and into the Victorian Riverina. >Italians
Yeah it's an interesting case. Landowners opted to bring more of them over as they thought they'd be more suited to Australia than British and their knowledge of farming in drier climates would be useful. Additionally, they were used as a more favourable alternative to Kanaks from New Caledonia for Queenslander plantations. It wasn't until they began to compete with British in mining that their immigration (along with Greeks and Hungarians) was restricted until the 1950s. Trade unions and the Labour Party lobbied to restrict them greatly, and by 1928, Italian immigration was limited to 2% of British immigration of the year.
A similiar thing happened with Greeks, who'd excelled in the pearling industry but when entering the mining industry, faced intense backlash by Anglo-Celtic Australians. It wasn't until WWII when many ANZACs fought in Greece and Crete and were offered great hospitality by Greeks, and fighting side by side that influenced opinion back home.
The fact that Mediterraneans were considered 'dark whites' or 'ethnics', often called wogs (which was/is also a slang for sickness, being the 'sickness of the nation'), produced an otherness which remains to this day in Australia, in spite of a great deal of assimilation, many Mediterraneans felt scorned and developed parallel societies, complete with their own industries, businesses, and cultural facilities. There's a great deal of pride in the intense labour used for massive infrastructure in Australia by the forebearers of their community, most prominently, the Snowy Mountains Scheme.

The Virtues of Geometry

Spinoza consistently used geometrical demonstrations to present his philosophical ideas. This is evident in the Ethics, Short Treatise, and Descartes’ Principles of Philosophy Demonstrated in the Geometric Manner. In Tractatus de Intellectu Emendatione, Spinoza talks about “a way of healing the intellect, and purifying it” that might precede geometrical demonstration but gives no definition of the intellect or any general procedure for acquiring true definitions. This chapter examines how one acquires these definitions, discussing first what Spinoza might have considered to be the advantages or virtues of geometrical demonstration: transparency, force, security, scale, compactness, flexibility, generality, and sense-independence. It then analyzes Spinoza’s relation to Descartes, highlighting the distinction between the analytic and the synthetic method, their different sense of geometrical order, and another virtue of geometry: ease. Finally, it invokes the idea of method Spinoza outlined in Emendatione as a solution to the puzzle mentioned earlier.

>>14441139
The issue with defaulting to 'energy' as a basic substrate is the unwieldy nature of its primary meaning. What we refer to as 'energy' is but a abstraction representation of the innate capacity of action that a given object possesses, i.e. of something influencing or causing a change in something else in a noticeable, observable, or scientifically measurable way (usually in the form of motion, which is the most basic phenomena of observable). But this definition loses its very coherence when we start talking about quantum fields as vectors of influence overlapping one another in spacetime; the ontology ceases to be about 'things' in the material sense and becomes 'digital' in the sense that discrete units of information become the foundation of reality. The overlapping fields are analogous to layers or subsystems of a complex information processing system that, taken together, produces and interprets the content of reality (i.e. of the cosmos). This is pretty much what theoretical physicists, mathematicians, and software programmers spend all their day doing; establishing frameworks or structures for the interpretation of data, and working out the relationships that exist among quantities and qualities (i.e. variables) and how they interact to produce more complex variables and larger or smaller quantities, depending on the operation/interaction.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14441139

Now, as even a child can understand, the meaning of information, whether it is linguistic, numerical, or visual, is dependent on the context in which it is presented. 1+1=2 only insomuch as the addition of identical discrete quantities yields a greater quantity which is itself specified as the sum of its antecedents. What this means is that there are necessary preconditions in any information system in order for there to be data; the interpretative apparatus cannot 'emerge' or 'develop' alongside the data, but rather stands behind it and makes it intelligible. Thus, even an A.I. that can 'learn' in the sense that it can develop functions beyond that of the programmer's initial coding is still limited by the constraints of its interpretive nexus, and, hence, the amount of data it can act upon. There can be no 'new' data apart from the discrete units of information that were already present in the system as a baseline, as well as the varying ways of combining them to form larger structures of meaning, itself a process utterly reliant upon the 'architecture' or interpretative grid of the system.

But where does data (i.e. the content reality) come from in the first place? After all, I mentioned above that there can be no 'new' data in the sense of information introduced by the system itself (i.e the contextual framework of rules for interpreting reality) outside that which it has been initially supplied. Both data and the program which interprets it must themselves be necessarily supplied by an external source, who in everyday software production and maintenance we refer to as the programmer. It is he or she that both writes the program as well as supplies the basic units of code that serve as signals for the conveying of information.

This elaborate example depicts the main thrust of the contingency argument as presented in modern terms.

Even though crime/mafia stories are usually ethnic, they're paradoxically one of the few things we have as a common culture that people kinda relate to, and they can rise to something almost like Shakespearean plays for the English or Greek tragedies. They're tragedies (and can be quite funny) where these goombas are trying to "make it" per the American Dream but they end up being undone or just as miserable (if not more so) than when they started (or they get killed and brought down).

The stories can make you think too: who is this guy, how he is related to that guy, what is he doing, etc. They deal with people's hypocrises:

https://youtu.be/bzVeLjj6Ao8

Fargo was one of the great crime movies too and it takes place in Minnesota and North Dakota, so it's also an "ethnic" film in a way but it's white people who live there and are descended from Scandinavian immigrants. Scarface took place in Miami in the 80s. The Sopranos, obviously, in New Jersey at the turn of the century. These American crime stories feel very "real" to us, like involving particular places and the real people who live there. The places or the particular time is as important as the individual characters.

That's just my theory.

Determinist or Necessitarian arguments like this one is the reason why most epicureans, both then and now, tended to be privileged types with a source of income not dependent on their low-achieving lifestyle. The possibility of exercising self-restraint or discipline in and of itself disproves this line of reasoning, as rational action directed towards a goal apart from natural (i.e. physical) constraints and incentives demonstrates the existence of desirable ends external to and transcending purely natural ones. It is why men lay down their lives for their country even if they possess no kin who will benefit directly from their sacrifice, and why certain people refuse to take bribes or slander someone even if they have assurances that they won't be caught. It is why the writer, painter, and dramatist forgoes experience of the material things that they depict via their craft; they are seeking the higher fulfillment of the ideal beauty or objective meaning that they hope to communicate.

When such reasoning fails the test of explaining the behavior and thoughts of men, of whom we possess firsthand knowledge and experience (both in regards to ourselves and to others), then how can it ever hope to be valid as regards to the divine, which is fundamentally unknowable and inaccessible to us, apart from that which can be reasonably inferred about it (i.e. its transcendence, eternity, omnipotence, etc) or by its direct disclosure of itself via special revelation? The Stoics, Platonists, and Peripatetics btfo'd this line of reasoning millennia ago, to say nothing of Jewish, Christian, and Muslim critiques.

Hence, this so-called 'problem' is a joke, and is only touted by midwit hedonists and fedorafags online who want to excuse themselves from moral obligations external to their own subjective dictates or whims of fancy. But, by all means, keep spamming the board with this shitty, recycled bait. It keeps the traffic coming and the ad revenue accruing.

>>14432409
From these pre-Incaic elements, the image could represent the ancient temple of Pachacamac, built in honor of the local god of the place, popular in much of the northern part of the Inca Empire, although the perspective seems more in line with the much larger and more recent Temple of the Sun built by the Incas.
The local non-Inca temple at Pachacamac was occupied by the Wari (among others), but when the Incas conquered the sactuary it was an Ichma temple and was painted with distinctive Ichma motifs (very diferent from Wari's), so it is also called the Painted Temple. In this temple survived a representation of the god Pachacamac, a wooden pole dating to the Wari period. As I said the Chavin were much older and all their sanctuaries and style had already been abandoned long ago, none surviving into the time of the Incas, not to mention that Chavin stone stelae are extremely rare and the few found are in the heart of Chavin, in its temple and nearby vicinity, not a single one has been found on the coast or so far away.

>>14432567
Knitting didn't exist in the pre-Columbian Andes, although they knew practically all other weaving techniques known today.

Similarly, ponchos appear to have been rare in comparison to today. Although they appear in some pre-Inca cultures (especially coastal ones) such as Paracas, for the most part they did not have the proportions of today's ponchos, the common attire of most highland provinces during the Inca empire was an uncu, which is a sleeveless tunic with a yacolla or blanket around it, which was still the common attire recorded in many parts in early colonial times, the rise in popularity of today's ponchos is rather hazy, but seems to have been an evolution of uncus from which the sides were left unstitched.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14441823
Visibility was the main issue. Whoever spots and shoots the other first usually wins in war, this applies to all forms of warfare, tank warfare, infantry warfare, air warfare, naval warfare, etc.

An enclosed bridge meant you were limited to looking through windows (which were limited in size, vulnerable in action, and collected spray and rain), which could suffer from distortion and reflections, and whose frames partly blocked your view. And, in more recent times, against dive bombers… you either need a glazed roof (good luck with that after the first near-miss) or you can’t see shit.

Visual spotting was always the primary means of detecting and tracking threats before radar, and open bridges allow better visibility. Larger ships had enclosed conning towers, and smaller vessels would have secondary control stations below decks, but for a long time the open bridge was preferred for the better visibility of the area it provided.
Unless, of course, you're a Korean turtle ship, whose job it is to literally charge like a retard right into the middle of a pack of big dumb Jap troop transport vessels and raise hell by shooting and ramming wildly everywhere. At that point it doesn't even really matter if your sails are shot away.

>>14441823
Because for the longest time naval battles weren't about sinking the other ship but driving the other ship off for forcing it to surrender. Since naval gunnery didn't exist, catapults cant hit shit accurately, premodern missiles aren't exactly that lethal, & ramming was very dangerous for both parties ships (even for the greeks who engineered theirs to be rammers), the best way to do that was to simply board the other guy and either kill them all or subdue & capture the ship & crew.

There were people who did see the logic of covering their ship's decks with additional fighting platforms & canopies were mainly the Chinese, Koreans, and the Japanese (as your pic shows), but this only resulted to ungainly, tall, and unmaneuverable warships that were shit at moving about. This was ok as much of the naval battles in that area were coastal/riverine, but when China became a seafaring nation, it led them to eventually abandon the fortress-ship design and opt for fighting junks that had only a single raised fighting deck ad even took cues from European design, like Fore-Aft Castles.

>>14441810
>In judaism, how is afterlife seen? Especially hell, is it vastly different from christian view?
Judaism is notoriously tight lipped on the afterlife, which is called "Olam Ha Ba," or "The World To Come." Some believe that it's a literal next phase to this world, where everything will be perfect and all the dead will be resurected. Others believe that it's a more traditional heavenly realm, or perhaps a retrun to the Garden of Eden. In general, it's not something worth worrying about in Judaism; God is good, so there's nothing to fear.

It is explicitly not a place just for Jews. Anyone from any nation can be righteous. The reward for following the Covenant is not the afterlife, but rather God's temporal protection of the Jewish nation.

The interpretation of afterlife that I subscribe to is that of Gehinom. Gehinom (or Gehenna) is not a place, but rather an emotion; a feeling of intense shame. When we die, we become beings of pure soul, and thus lose our physical bodies and physical insticts. The human inclination to sin comes entirely from physical instinct, so the first emotion that every human being feels upon rising to heaven is the shame of Gehinom, comiserate to how much they sinned in life.

This is the only "punishment" one recieves after they die. One must atone for their the sins and regrets of their life in heaven, often by approaching the souls of those they hurt when alive and asking their forgiveness directly. They choose to attone not because it is forced on them, but because it is the natural desire of every soul to be good. Those who lived righteous lives will very quickly escape Gehinom and will get to enjoy heaven. Those who were wicked in life will struggle against Gehinom for longer, but it is never a permanent state; one has endless time to atone while in heaven.

Some rabbis also say that all souls are freed from Gehinom during the sabbath, so even those under its burden are not completely overwhelmed by it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you haven't read this book, you don't understand WW2. period.

>Were Hitler and the Nazis were just a bunch of idiots doing crazy irrational decisions
Nope, this book lays out all the logic behind their decisions. It's fucked up, but it's consistent.
>Why did Germany declare war on America
They viewed Roosevelt as the leader of a sinister Jewish international alliance against them, and thought that war with America was inevitable. They could have delayed it a little more, but they wanted to show support for Japan, their only major ally.
>Didn't they know that America had a much stronger economy
Yes, and all of their plans were based around building up their own economy (by conquering territory) and ending the war before America could fully get its shit together for war.
>Why did they declare war on the USSR
See above. They needed more land and resources to have any chance against America, and they felt that a quick knockout victory against the USSR was the only way to do it.
>Why did they attack Poland, Norway, and France
Same reason. These three gambles worked, Barbarossa didn't. The blitzkreig into France was a crazy gambit they pulled out of their ass at the last minute.
>Why were they so shit at building tanks and ships
Partly because their entire economy was shit. They had more horses than cars, their most common occupation was "peasant farmer," and they were completely fucked by the British naval blockade and US sanctions. It's a marvel they could produce any modern military equipment at all.
But also because the majority of their war effort went into the luftwaffe, especially the heavy bomber program. They believed (as did the UK and US pre-war strategists) that strategic bombing would be the most decisive weapon of the war. They thought a heavy strategic bombing campaign would be both unstoppable and enough to bring a country to its knees, sort of like how we think of nuclear missiles today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14442084
>Why did they do the holocaust
Partly because they were crazy anti-semitic assholes. But also for strategic reasons. They didn't have enough food to feed everyone, so it made sense to choose some people to work and starve to death.
>Could they have won
Maybe. The odds were certainly against them, since their economy was so shit. But they also wasted a ton of resources on the strategic bomber program that went nowhere. The fall of France completely fucked the Allies and gave Germany a ton of free weapons and resources, and all the Allies were too slow to rearm. Germany had a chance in 1940/41, but didn't start seriously building tanks and submarines until about 1942/43 when it was way too late. If they had listened to Donitz/Guderion/Manstein instead of sucking of Goering for the entire war, things could have gone very differently.
>Why did the USSR outproduce everyone
Because the USSR actually focused its entire economy on tanks and artillery that worked, instead of useless heavy bombers. They also pulled all their farmers into the war effort, and would have starved to death if they hadn't gotten lend-lease and also reconquered territory.

What I don't understand is the meme that somehow Germany did not have war economy on part with the Soviet Union. Which is obviously false from the pespective a western economy, but different from teh Soviet command/collectivized economy.

Germany had essentialy a war economy since 1939 but of a different type, its not like the dependent on civilian industries and slave labor alone. Germany requisitioned workers and machinery on the fly. In fact the system was frightngly sucessful and factories were producing tiger tanks as late as 1944 and early 1945.

Germany theoretically was never fully mechanized, but had Barbarossa went more in their favor and was more drawn out war, they would have continued producing more tanks and vehicles. Even with the limited oil reserves they had. Had the eastern front been less extended and more narrow in terms of battles and seiges, the war would have gone on way longer than 1945 even with the US in France.

Historians tend to understimate Nazi Germany in ww2 , but there were glaring strategic mistakes made that turned the war in their disfavor very quickly in 1943. Barbarossa at the beggining was not as lop sided as many think, nor that much doomed to fail as Tooze insists.

Fascism is deliberately vague and hard-to-define.

>The Vagueness of the Fascist Programme: There are certain curious features about this Fascism. There has been no efficient fight against it, even when the danger has been understood long beforehand, and there is not yet even a satisfactory explanation of what Fascism is. >Mussolini used to say: ‘What we need is not a programme but action.’ Mosley in his early days took this as his slogan, and becomes the less effective the more he departs from this attitude. >In his early days, when he was preparing for his first bid for power, Hitler in a speech made in 1923 declared: ‘Let us first begin to rule, then the programme will come quite by itself.’ – a statement that would be received with roars of laughter in any Socialist or Liberal conference. >The Main Contradictions in Fascism: This vague, ambiguous, elusive character of the party which has been regarded as a main argument against Fascism supplies, in fact, the key to the understanding of it.

>We live in an age of transition – and that does not necessarily imply that the transition period is a brief one. The transition from feudal to capitalist society lasted approximately 400 years. The changeover from a horse to a horsepower civilisation has been going on for over a hundred years with all the changes and stresses in social structure that intensified mass production brings. The big jump that has now to be made is the changeover from an individualistic to a collective, from an anarchic to a planned economy.

>Fascism is the political form of one of the stages in this transition, that stage in which we now are. All the antagonistic and contradictory tendencies are somehow united in it. >The Minor Contradictions in Fascism: Owing to the general contradictions within Fascism a number of minor contradictions exist. There is the inevitable struggle between the policy of preserving the ‘old’ middle classes, their local status and independence, and the desire for a plan which would make superfluous many functions that the old middle class performed. There is the contradiction between the attempt to lower the standard of the workers, dictated by the capitalist elements in Fascism, and the war preparations which need a reasonably contented working class. There is the incompatibility of autarchy and conquest of foreign markets: between the return to the village economy and war. The return to the village means the extinction of the heavy industry which is indispensable to the needs of the militarists. To see only one side of these contradictions as real, and to assume that the other is there for window-dressing purposes, makes it impossible to understand Fascism and the necessary zig-zaggery of Fascist policy.

>It is the Leader who keeps together and maintains the equilibrium between the contradictory elements and groups. Therefore each Fascist party has one thing at least in common... a leader. >>14441587
I'll share what little I know, but I'm no expert.

Ancient Greece is the basis of all western civilization, because they heavily influenced Rome; they were also heavily influenced by Egypt. Greece is a massively bifurcated region with thousands of islands, peninsulas, and dozens of dominant kingdoms. They were plagued by war and infighting (see the Peloponnesian war, Trojan war, etc.) which prevented them from becoming a major world power until the Hellenic period but their technology and culture had a huge impact.

They collectively benefited and grew upon being a trading partner between the Nile and the fertile crescent. They were good at ships and trade and prospered benefiting from both regions because their geography and therefore culture was very water-based and had multiple independent governments. Of course ancient Greek culture came from an even earlier culture known as the Minoan civilization based on Crete which we sadly don't know much about.

That's just the background, to answer your question: the Athenians are the best because they invented democracy and philosophy. The Spartans are the best because they perfected warfare. The Macedonians are best because they conquered the known world.

Marriage fulfils three functions. Social, Religious, and Political/Economic. The religious aspect should be outside the realm of government - and if a church wants to preform a ceremony for gay couples then that's a matter for that church's leadership and congregation. The social aspect is to announce to your friends and family that you think that this relationship is the one you want to keep from now on (although given divorce stats there's some debate about how much this applies now), but again that's not something that you need a government's or church's permission for, just throw a party and announce it. The reason that marriage has legislation around it is for the last one there, the economic factor. A stable, loving, supportive heterosexual family has been proven time and time again to be the best scenario to breed and produce children (the next generation of citizens and workers, hence the government's interest in it). There isn't sufficient data to tell us how gay parents will compare to that just yet - and for such a polarising issue it is almost impossible for a fair and honest study to be conducted/published - but let's be real and acknowledge that at its best it can only be as good as a functional heterosexual marriage, just without the ability to actually breed their own children.

As such it is, in the absolute best possible case, a second rate set up for fulfilling the task of a marriage (from the perspective of the government, the people you are arguing should be involved). Why are you in favour of the state wasting its limited and already overstretched resources on an, at best, second rate set up OP? Your fee-fees are not a political issue. Grow up. Enjoy life with your homosexual partner and stop trying to bother the rest of us.

Some distinctive Ahmadi beliefs are:

1. Denial that Muhammad is the final prophet of God, he was only the last law bearing prophet.

5. The swoon theory of Jesus's crucifixon. They believed he was truly crucified, but survived it, and fled to India afterwards where they believe his tomb is located. They reject the literal second coming of Jesus.
6. Acceptance of many non-Abrahamic figures as prophets including Krishna, Zoroaster, Buddha and Confucius.
7. Denial of the traditional view that parts of the Qur'an are abrogated.
8. Belief that time is divided into several epochs, mirroring the seven days of creation.

Other than this they more or less resemble Sunni Islam. They affirm Tawhid, they affirm all five pillars of Islam, they pray like Sunnis, they use the same Hadiths as Sunnis, they accept the Sunni Caliphs, they love Aisha, the Qur'an is their central text (they have their own unique translation though, like how JWs have the NWT Bible), they consider the Qur'an the final divine words sent to mankind, celebrate Ramadan, etc.

A simplistic view but yes grain based diets did not produce a healthy population but it does provide a stable population and allows for the storage of food over droughts and famines etc. A big advantage over hunter gatherers.

They were commonly conquered by Normandic pastoralists peoples who had a high meat diet partly because they tended to be stronger and more fierce but also because agriculture usually requires flat land near a flood plain. These lands are hard to defend against highly mobile horse riding pastoralists. The pastoralists tended to adopt the lifestyle and practices of the agriculturalists and the cycle would then repeat itself.

This isn't even ancient history. You can see the same thing playing out in the sahel in modern times.

Id+ego=superego (archetype of good, or a “god”)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The poor relations between Nixon and Congress that would culminate in Watergate began early in his administration, and they started over the appointment of Supreme Court Justices. Part of the president's '68 campaign pledges had involved the assertion that the judicial branch had been overtaken by liberal activism in the past 30 years and he would appoint constitutional conservatives to the Federal judiciary. The appointment of Warren Berger as new Chief Justice went smoothly enough, but shortly afterwards Justice Abe Fortas retired from the USSC unexpectedly. His initial choice to replace Fortas was Justice Clement Haynsworth of South Carolina, then sitting on the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals. This move was in line with Nixon's desire to extend the olive branch to the South, which had snubbed in terms of appointments to the judiciary and the Federal bureaucracy--attending Duke University as a young man had brought him into contact with Southern society and he had become a convert to the idea that it was necessary to move past the Civil War and accept Southerners as Americans, too.

Predictably, a pitchfork mob comprised of various factions formed to oppose Haynsworth's appointment. Civil rights groups were outraged at the idea of a Southerner sitting on the Supreme Court. Organized labor feared that Haynsworth, coming from a region with a traditional antipathy to labor unions, would be hostile to their interests. Jewish groups were also opposed to Haynsworth, not because he'd done anything anti-Semitic, but because appointing him meant that the Supreme Court would not have a Jewish member for the first time since 1915, and they'd come to feel entitled to having a representative on the bench. Nixon angrily replied that Supreme Court seats were just Supreme Court seats and there was no Jewish seat or Negro seat.
posts.filename: nixon announces end of bretton-woods economic system

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It then came out that Haynsworth had been involved in a minor conflict of interest involving a court case he handled where the plaintiff was a company he owned a few shares in. A minor "scandal" but enough to torpedo his nomination. While this was going on, the White House raised a call for the removal of liberal icon William O. Douglas from the Court. Douglas had been involved in far more improprieties and conflicts of interest than Haynsworth, but it didn't matter for much. Haynsworth's nomination folded for the simple reason that he was conservative and a Southerner.

Nixon tried again by appointing Harrold Carswell of Florida, then sitting on the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals. Unfortunately, Carswell was not only less than an outstanding jurist and intellect but earlier in his career had supported Jim Crow. The Senate voted against him 51-45, making Nixon the first president since Grover Cleveland to have two consective Supreme Court nominees rejected. The president then nominated a Minnesotan, Harry Blackmun, and later on would nominate two more Supreme Court Justices, William Rehnquist and Lewis Powell. The Senate, having no desire for further argument, quickly approved all three.

A few days after the double rejection of Haynsworth and Carswell, Nixon made a televised speech saying that he regretted his inability to appoint a Southerner and a constitutional conservative to the USSC. He went on to say that both justices were wrongly smeared with the accusation of white supremacy when their real sin was supporting a strict interpretation of the Constitution, and having been born in the South. This speech was thoroughly touching to Southerners and no doubt aided in his sweep of the region in the 1972 presidential election.

posts.com:
In all the gloating over Nixon's unprecedented landslide on November 7, 1972, the ugly truth was that it had failed to translate downballot, and Congress remained solidly under Democrat control, rendering the president effectively a head without a body. The new 93rd Congress was also itching for a fight, in no small part to avenge the "shameful defeat" of the '72 presidential race. Congress started by attempting to restrain the president's control over foreign policy, which had not been seriously challenged since the Neutrality Acts of 1935. Noted liberal historian Arthur Schlesinger published the book "The Imperial Presidency", widely circulated on college campuses, which charged Nixon with disregarding the system of checks and balances, and of ruling by executive fiat.

It was an unfair hit job on the president to be sure. After all, Democrat administrations going back to Wilson had been guilty of far greater abuse of executive privilege, spying on political opponents, and using executive orders to bypass Congress, and Nixon could have pointed out with complete accuracy that Schlesinger and friends looked the other way when FDR or LBJ did it. However, Democrats in Congress were not especially interested in arguing over which party's presidents had been dirtier. Instead, they hoped to fashion a narrative similar to the English civil war in which Parliament came to blows with a tyrannous king.

Democrat Congressional strength during the 1973-75 term was also substantial indeed, and Nixon was the first president since Zachary Taylor to begin his term with the opposition party having a majority in both houses. If a battle between president and Congress occurred, he stood little chance of winning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Questionable 1960s mental health care and sentencing practices meant that justice was inadequately served for the murder of a grade schooler by a jilted Ohio housewife. Shaker Heights, a safe, clean middle class Cleveland suburb, was not the kind of place one expected a child to be gunned down in cold blood. Mariann Kautz, a native of Dayton, married Robert Colby shortly after WWII. The couple moved to Shaker Heights in 1952 where Robert worked as an engineer, and welcomed their son Dane into the world a little bit later.

Like a lot of housewives in the idyllic Eisenhower years, Mariann began suffering considerable boredom and soon took to pursuing a young man she knew named John Young. Young was not interested in a married woman and rebuffed her advances. Mariann persisted and continued to stalk him, even when he was on a date with another woman. Young eventually told her husband about this and it appeared that Robert Colby gave her a good talking to, for she calmed down and quit chasing other men.

Unfortunately, in the late 1950s, the Colbys changed residences and moved to a new house a mere two blocks from John Young and his now wife Nancy, who had a young son of their own named Cremer. Cremer and Dane Colby became playmates but the Youngs did not want anything to do with his mother and discouraged the friendship. Furthermore, Nancy Young claimed that Dane was a slow learner, clumsy, and a bully to other children.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In April 1963, Mariann purchased a vintage Model 1902 Smith & Wesson .32 revolver and 50 rounds of ammo from a local gun shop, giving her name as "Mrs. Nancy Russell." One year later, in spring 1964, she called the Youngs to complain that she had not been invited to their Christmas party last December and that Nancy Young had refused to babysit for Dane on previous occasions. She'd also hit the Youngs' two children before, which did not improve relations between the two families. While Nancy was somewhat successful in calming down Mariann's temper, the latter believed John was out to get her for her past romantic advances on him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On the morning of Tuesday, August 24, 1965, Mariann called Nancy on the phone. She was in bed recovering from a sprained ankle so John took the call instead. Mariann claimed that Cremer had left his jacket over at her place and he should come and retrieve it. Cremer dutifully went off to get the jacket. When he failed to immediately come home, John and Nancy assumed he was just off playing with Dane somewhere. However, as hours passed with no sign of Cremer anywhere the two started to get worried. John called Mariann on the phone and she said that Cremer had come, gotten his jacket, and left, and she hadn't seen him since.

Around midday, a University of Ohio student was walking his dog in Gates Mills, about 10 miles away, and came across a child's body in a patch of woods. A Boy Scout sticker attached to one of his shoes read "Cremer the Lion." Cremer, sadly, had been found and it was readily apparent that he had died of a gunshot wound to the back of the head.

It didn't take long for police to focus their suspicion on Mariann. They questioned her about two weeks after the body was found and she said that Dane had accidentally shot Cremer while they were outside playing. But ballistics tests of her Smith & Wesson revolver (which had been found stowed in a freezer behind 3 pounds of hamburger meat) found that the gun had a quite heavy trigger action that required considerable force to activate, and it seemed slightly unbelievable that an 8 year old boy would have the strength needed to depress the trigger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After this claim was thoroughly exploded, Mariann admitted that she did shoot Cremer, but it was all a horrible accident. She said Cremer had come over to her house on August 24 to retrieve his coat, he was hanging out in the basement where Mariann kept her laundry and washer and dryer, and that she was unaware that the gun was underneath some sheets (a most unusual place to store a firearm). As she picked up the sheets, they snagged the trigger, firing the weapon into the back of Cremer's head.

Notwithstanding that the Smith & Wesson had already been demonstrated to not be able to fire without some force applied to it, there was also the uncomfortable fact that Cremer's head had powder burns which indicated it had been fired at close range. Cleveland police, unimpressed with Mariann's story, arrested her for first degree murder.

At her trial in Cuyahuga County Superior Court, prosecutor George Moscarino stated his belief that the shooting was cold-blooded murder of a young child. It was believed that Mariann had deliberately fired the .32 revolver two inches from Cremer's head, wrapped the body in a coat (later burned to destroy incriminating bloodstains), and dumped the body in the woods around Gates Mills. It had been reported by neighbors that she was seen to be driving the family's blue Ford station wagon out the driveway on the morning of August 24, around the time Cremer disappeared.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mariann's public defender Gerald Gold however argued that his client was legally insane, and had been confirmed by two psychiatrists, Dr. Lily Brunschwig and Dr. Arthur Rosenbaum, as such. They maintained that she had a pathological inability to tell right from wrong, and suffered from schizophrenia. Dr. Rosenbaum said that he believed she'd originally purchased the Smith & Wesson revolver with the intent of shooting John Young for having rejected her advances all those years ago.

On March 25, 1966, Judge Don Lybarger ruled Mariann Colby not guilty by reason of insanity and sentenced her to the Lima State Hospital for the Criminally Insane. She was released in 1972, after just six years, remarried to a man named Russell Cordle, and apparently lived out the rest of her life quietly. Mariann passed away on March 26, 2007 at the age of 82; she had been residing in Dublin, Ohio at the time of her death. Robert Colby remarried and had another son with his second wife; he eventually moved to Lynchburg, Virginia and died there in 2008 at the age of 87.

Cremer Young was laid to rest in Cleveland's Lake View Cemetery. John and Nancy Young, still living in the Cleveland area, passed away in 2010 and '11, respectively.

>Frederick also asked the French philosopher Voltaire to live with him at Sanssouci. When Voltaire left, he took with him poems by Frederick mocking other rulers that could compromise Frederick. Frederick had his agents detain Voltaire in Frankfurt am Main on his way back to France and forced him to surrender the poems.[18] This episode, which has been called a "lover's quarrel",[19] cooled Frederick and Voltaire's friendship. Eventually, they resumed their correspondence, aired their mutual recriminations, and remained on friendly terms until Voltaire's death.[2]

>Initially, Frederick William considered marrying Frederick to Elisabeth of Mecklenburg-Schwerin, the niece of Empress Anna of Russia, but this plan was ardently opposed by Prince Eugene of Savoy. He had little in common with his bride, and the marriage was resented as an example of the Austrian political interference that had plagued Prussia.[37] Nevertheless, during their early married life, the royal couple resided at the Crown Prince's Palace in Berlin. Later, Elisabeth Christine accompanied Frederick to Schloss Rheinsberg, where at this time she played an active role in his social life.[38] After his father died and he had secured the throne, Frederick separated from Elisabeth. He granted her the Schönhausen Palace and apartments at the Berliner Stadtschloss, but he prohibited Elisabeth Christine from visiting his court in Potsdam. Frederick and Elisabeth Christine had no children, and Frederick bestowed the title of the heir to the throne, "Prince of Prussia", on his brother Augustus William. Nevertheless, Elisabeth Christine remained devoted to him. Frederick gave her all the honours befitting her station, but never displayed any affection. After their separation, he would only see her on state occasions.[39] These included visits to her on her birthday and were some of the rare occasions when Frederick did not wear military uniform.[40]
